title: 112_s433
content: The "Free and Fair Trade Act of 2011" may be cited as the Act. It includes an extension of the Generalized System of Preferences. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to extend the deadline to June 30, 2012. The amendment applies to goods entered after the enactment date. Retroactive application is allowed for certain liquidations and reliquidations. The Trade Act of 1974 amendment extends the deadline to June 30, 2012 for goods entered after the enactment date. Liquidation or reliquidation requests must be filed with U.S. Customs and Border Protection within 180 days of the enactment date. The Trade Act of 1974 amendment extends the deadline for goods entered after the enactment date to June 30, 2012. Liquidation or reliquidation requests must be filed with U.S. Customs and Border Protection within 180 days. Any amounts owed by the United States for an entry of an article must be paid within 90 days of liquidation or reliquidation. The term "entry" includes a withdrawal from warehouse for consumption. SEC. 3 amends the Trade Act of 1974 to exclude certain sleeping bags from preferential treatment under the Generalized System of Preferences. This amendment applies to articles entered after the enactment date. SEC. 4 extends the Andean Trade Preference Act. The Andean Trade Preference Act is amended to extend the deadline to June 30, 2012. Certain apparel articles are also affected by the amendment, allowing for 9 succeeding 1-year periods and a 4-year period. The Andean Trade Preference Act is amended to extend the deadline to June 30, 2012, allowing for 8 succeeding 1-year periods. The amendments apply to articles entered on or after the 15th day after the enactment of the Act. The Andean Trade Preference Act is amended to extend the deadline for preferential treatment to June 30, 2012, with 8 additional 1-year periods. Entries made after February 12, 2011, but before the 15th day after the enactment of this Act, can be liquidated or reliquidated as if they occurred 15 days after the enactment. Requests for liquidation or reliquidation must be filed within 180 days of the Act's enactment with U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The term "entry" in this subsection includes a withdrawal from warehouse for consumption. Any amounts owed by the United States for the liquidation or reliquidation of an entry must be paid within 90 days without interest. SEC. 5. OFFSET. $2.3 billion in unobligated Federal funds are rescinded. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must identify and report on the accounts and amounts to be rescinded within 60 days. This does not apply to funds of the Department of Defense or Veterans Affairs. SEC. 6. COMPLIANCE WITH PAYGO. SEC. 6. COMPLIANCE WITH PAYGO. The budgetary effects of this Act must comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010, as determined by the latest statement submitted by the Chairman of the Senate Budget Committee before the vote on passage.
